Hey idk if u Still need it but the potential energy held in each capacitor simply because the voltage across each capacitor is diff.   U= ½CV² U=½(CV)V       [Q=CV] U=½QV  In series Q is the same but voltage isn't. Hope this helps

See the video for exponential notation on YouTube you'll get know then... Since you have 5×10^-3, it means you have to put the decimal point 3 positions before the 5. You have, 5 in which the decimal point is at the end like this 5.  Just put it three times before One time .5 Second time .05 Third time .005 And now before decimal point there is no number that means it's zero  Therefore, 0.005  I hope it helped you 👍

Dimitrios Fotopoulos oh ok, i think now though that maybe PE=qv is used to measure the total potential energy in a circuit through a moving charge while U=1/2cv2 is for the potential energy inside the capacitor.
@parkkinglot892  Oh wait a sec I know why you get different numbers

@parkkinglot892  we use q×V only when v is constant but when it comes to capacitors V is changing through time because the one plate of negative charge is discharging through time and for that reason we do the diagram of v with respect to time and we find that it formes a triangle I think because from my experience with physics this diagram must form a triangle if not it would be a parabola wich means you would find the answer with calculus
Dimitrios Fotopoulos ahw.ok i see, does it also.depend.if the circuit is.parallel.or.in series?
@parkkinglot892  anyway because I haven t really searched on this topic a lot don t trust me with the maths behind of where this equations comes from but I know that it comes from a diagram

@parkkinglot892  not really no but if for example you had 3 capacitors and were parrarel you would first have to add them so that you find the overall capacitance and then the V of the capacitance and then use this V with the previous equation to solve for the overall energy that was stored in the overall capacitor if you want the enegy stored in a specific capacitor then do the same thing with the v and energy equation withought adding any other capacitor

@parkkinglot892  btw I forgot to mention you that the first pE=q×V equation does work but it only works when the V is constant and but if want to meassure an electron s PE withought the other elextron s leaving the xharged plate this equation wlrks just fine
When the capacitor is in parallel, the equiv. Capacitance is equal to the summation of it. When its in series, the equiv. Capacitance is in parallel method just like resistance.

Zoe Adams how is it a complete circuit if theres open air between the capacitors. im new to this, and it seems like it would be an open switch

@trace8617  youre right, its not. The electrons build on one side, and because lots of electrons have a large negative charge, they repel the electrons in the other plate and those electrons continue the circuit. So one plate builds up electrons and the other loses electrons.
